prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 5 unique high redshift ULIRGs for which we have existing mid-IR spectroscopy and far-IR imaging, allowing us to measure the emission properties of the dust in the ISM and quantify heating from an embedded AGN. We now propose to measure the CO excitation ladder for these sources, providing a robust view of the gas and dust in the ISM in ULIRGs at z=1-2.
Expected Source Properties: In Science Goal 1, we will observe the J(2-1) transition. We calculate our sensitivities from LIR. With our rich data set, including far-IR/submm photometry, we have performed detailed SED fitting to obtain accurate values of LIR. LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor either for SMGs (typically undergoing mergers) or normal SF galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). We have estimated the sensitivity in 2 ways. 1) 2 of our sources, GS_IRS30 and GS_IRS64, are undisturbed disks with minimal AGN emission in the mid-IR. For these galaxies, we calculate LCO using the conversion for normal SF galaxies. 2) 3 of our sources, while having luminosities an order of magnitude less than the typical SMG, either possess a luminous AGN or signs of a merger. For these galaxies, we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO.
We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(2-1). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 3 hr 43 min, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS12 CO(2-1) Peak Flux: 1.81 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.36 mJy GS_IRS13 CO(2-1) Peak Flux: 2.80 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.56 mJy GS_IRS30 CO(2-1) Peak Flux: 1.64 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.33 mJy GS_IRS45 CO(2-1) Peak Flux: 5.34 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.07 mJy GS_IRS64 CO(2-1) Peak Flux: 2.02 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.40 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe in Band 3. Four of our sources lie at the same redshift, so we have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (88.67 GHz and 87.99 GHz). We place the 2 remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5"resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and we choose the standard calibration.

Background: We propose CO measurements of 5 unique high redshift ULIRGs for which we have existing mid-IR spectroscopy and far-IR imaging, allowing us to measure the emission properties of the dust in the ISM and quantify heating from an embedded AGN. We now propose to measure the CO excitation ladder for these sources, providing a robust view of the gas and dust in the ISM in ULIRGs at z=1-2.
Expected Source Properties: In Science Goal 2, we will observe the J(3-2) transition. We calculate our sensitivities from LIR. With our rich data set, including far-IR/submm photometry, we have performed detailed SED fitting to obtain accurate values of LIR. LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor either for SMGs (typically undergoing mergers) or normal SF galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). We have estimated the sensitivity in 2 ways. 1) 2 of our sources, GS_IRS30 and GS_IRS64, are undisturbed disks with minimal AGN emission in the mid-IR. For these galaxies, we calculate LCO using the conversion for normal SF galaxies. 2) 3 of our sources, while having luminosities an order of magnitude less than the typical SMG, either possess a luminous AGN or signs of a merger. For these galaxies, we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO.
We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(3-2). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 2 hr 51 min, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS12 CO(3-2) Peak Flux: 2.67 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.54 mJy GS_IRS13 CO(3-2) Peak Flux: 4.16 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.83 mJy GS_IRS30 CO(3-2) Peak Flux: 2.22 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.44 mJy GS_IRS45 CO(3-2) Peak Flux: 7.93 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.59 mJy GS_IRS64 CO(3-2) Peak Flux: 2.74 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.55 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe in Band 4. Four of our sources lie at the same redshift, so we have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (131.983 GHz and 132.998 GHz). We place the 2 remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5"resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and we choose the standard calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Copy of Science Goal

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 5 unique high redshift ULIRGs for which we have existing mid-IR spectroscopy and far-IR imaging, allowing us to measure the emission properties of the dust in the ISM and quantify heating from an embedded AGN. We now propose to measure the CO excitation ladder for these sources, providing a robust view of the gas and dust in the ISM in ULIRGs at z=1-2.
Expected Source Properties: In Science Goal 3, we will observe the J(5-4) transition. We calculate our sensitivities from LIR. With our rich data set, including far-IR/submm photometry, we have performed detailed SED fitting to obtain accurate values of LIR. LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor either for SMGs (typically undergoing mergers) or normal SF galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). We have estimated the sensitivity in 2 ways. 1) 2 of our sources, GS_IRS30 and GS_IRS64, are undisturbed disks with minimal AGN emission in the mid-IR. For these galaxies, we calculate LCO using the conversion for normal SF galaxies. 2) 3 of our sources, while having luminosities an order of magnitude less than the typical SMG, either possess a luminous AGN or signs of a merger. For these galaxies, we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO.
Only conversions for SMGs are known for the higher order transitions, and to convert between J(5-4) and J(1-0), we must first interpolate a conversion factor using what has been measured in SMGs for the J(4-3) and J(6-5) transistions. As such, our calculated flux densities are likely lower than what we will observe. We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 1 hr 13 min, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS12 CO(5-4) Peak Flux: 4.45 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.89 mJy GS_IRS13 CO(5-4) Peak Flux: 6.89 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.38 mJy GS_IRS30 CO(5-4) Peak Flux: 3.70 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.74 mJy GS_IRS45 CO(5-4) Peak Flux: 13.1 mJy 5sigma rms: 2.62 mJy GS_IRS64 CO(5-4) Peak Flux: 4.56 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.91 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe in Band 6. Four of our sources lie at the same redshift, so we have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (219.95 GHz and 221.64 GHz). We place the 2 remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5"resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and we choose the standard calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Copy of Copy of Science Goal

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 5 unique high redshift ULIRGs for which we have existing mid-IR spectroscopy and far-IR imaging, allowing us to measure the emission properties of the dust in the ISM and quantify heating from an embedded AGN. We now propose to measure the CO excitation ladder for these sources, providing a robust view of the gas and dust in the ISM in ULIRGs at z=1-2.
Expected Source Properties: In Science Goal 4, we will observe the J(6-5) transition. We calculate our sensitivities from LIR. With our rich data set, including far-IR/submm photometry, we have performed detailed SED fitting to obtain accurate values of LIR. LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor either for SMGs (typically undergoing mergers) or normal SF galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). We have estimated the sensitivity in 2 ways. 1) 2 of our sources, GS_IRS30 and GS_IRS64, are undisturbed disks with minimal AGN emission in the mid-IR. For these galaxies, we calculate LCO using the conversion for normal SF galaxies. 2) 3 of our sources, while having luminosities an order of magnitude less than the typical SMG, either possess a luminous AGN or signs of a merger. For these galaxies, we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO.
For the J(6-5) transition, only the conversion for SMGs has been measured, so we use that value to calculate the expected flux density of this transition, though this is a conservative estimate, and our sources will likely be brighter. We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 1 hr 31 min, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS12 CO(6-5) Peak Flux: 4.09 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.82 mJy GS_IRS13 CO(6-5) Peak Flux: 6.33 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.27 mJy GS_IRS30 CO(6-5) Peak Flux: 3.73 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.75 mJy GS_IRS45 CO(6-5) Peak Flux: 12.1 mJy 5sigma rms: 2.41 mJy GS_IRS64 CO(6-5) Peak Flux: 3.40 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.92 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe in Band 6. Four of our sources lie at the same redshift, so we have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (263.92 GHz and 265.95 GHz). We place the 2 remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5"resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and we choose the standard calibration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Conditions in the ISM can be probed through measurements of the CO spectral line energy distribution (SLED) since the shape of the CO SLED is dependent on the density and temperature of the molecular gas. Most measurements of the CO SLED at high z are in QSOs and submillimeter galaxies. However, the energetics of these two populations differ substantially from each other and from locally observed star forming galaxies.
The bulk of stellar mass is being formed in main sequence galaxies, yet relatively little is known about their molecular gas energetics at high z. We propose to obtain the CO SLED, out to J(6-5), in a sample of main sequence ULIRGs. We will use the observed SLED to calculate the molecular gas density and temperatures. Furthermore, 2 ULIRGs host an enshrouded AGN, according to decomposition of mid-IR spectroscopy. We have quantified the effect the AGN is having on the dust, and now we will measure the effect on the excitation of the molecular gas. Our wealth of data quantifying the dust and interstellar radiation field, including mid-IR spectroscopy and far-IR imaging, make our sources ideal for a pilot study of the gas energetics in high z main sequence galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00167.S, Probing the ISM of AGN and Star Forming Galaxies During the Peak Epoch of Star Formation, P.I. Allison Kirkpatrick
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
